title: About Me
text: This project was completed by Chi-Hyun Kim, as part of the final project for MUSA 550, Geospatial Data Science in Python

title: Clustering analysis
text:
import pandas as pd
import geopandas as gpd
import numpy as np
import altair as alt
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import re

from sklearn.impute import KNNImputer
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.decomposition import PCA
from sklearn.cluster import KMeans
from sklearn.compose import ColumnTransformer
In this section, we apply unsupervised learning techniques to glean further insights into any systematic patterns in the turnout change. First, we use Principal Components Analysis (PCA) to reduce the dimensionality of the data to a few orthogonal features. Then, we use K-means clustering to categorize Philadelphia precincts by how their politico-socioeconomic characteristics interacted with turnout change.

title: Clustering analysis
text:
Preparations
First, any missing values in the data (which are restricted to the demographic features) are imputed using k-nearest-neighbor imputation. Then, the input features are normalized by removing the mean and scaling the values to unit variance, so that different numerical orders of magnitude in the data (e.g., percentages vs income) do not bias the analysis. (The final variable of interest, percentage point difference in turnout, is not scaled yet since it will not be used in PCA.)

# Prepare data for preprocessing
input_data = gpd.read_file('data/prepared_data.geojson')  

# Drop columns which will not be used
data_to_preprocess = pd.DataFrame(input_data.drop(columns='geometry'))
data_to_preprocess = data_to_preprocess[['turnout_2020', 'pres_d_share_2024', 'pres_d_share_2020', 
                                         'demographics_median_income', 'demographics_black_percentage', 'demographics_latino_percentage', 
                                         'demographics_renter_percentage', 'demographics_university_percentage']]
data_remaining = input_data[['precinct', 'turnout_change', 'geometry']]


# Impute missing values

# Create imputer
imputer = KNNImputer()

# Fit and transform
df_imputed = imputer.fit_transform(data_to_preprocess)


# Standardize
scaler = StandardScaler()
df_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(df_imputed)

title: Clustering analysis
text:
PCA
The scaled values are fed into PCA, which decomposes the 8 input features into components which in order capture the largest variation in the data. The plot below shows that the increasing amount of variance explained by each added component slows significantly after n = 3; therefore, we take the first 3 components from now on.

# Fit PCA on scaled data
pca = PCA().fit(df_scaled)

# Plotting the Cumulative Summation of the Explained Variance
plt.figure()
plt.plot(range(1, len(pca.explained_variance_ratio_) + 1), 
         np.cumsum(pca.explained_variance_ratio_))
plt.xlabel('Number of Components')
plt.ylabel('Cumulative Explained Variance')
plt.title('Explained Variance by Different Principal Components')
plt.show()









pca_components = 3
pca = PCA(n_components=pca_components)

pca_result = pca.fit_transform(df_scaled)


# Get the PCA components (loadings)
pca_components = pca.components_

# Create a DataFrame for better visualization and analysis
pca_loadings_df = pd.DataFrame(pca_components, columns=data_to_preprocess.columns, index=[f'PC{i+1}' for i in range(pca.n_components)])

# Display the loadings
pca_loadings_df








turnout_2020
pres_d_share_2024
pres_d_share_2020
demographics_median_income
demographics_black_percentage
demographics_latino_percentage
demographics_renter_percentage
demographics_university_percentage




PC1
0.343400
-0.473615
-0.487833
0.345370
-0.406522
0.003958
-0.338614
-0.143416

-0.494649
-0.261914
-0.210295
-0.265396

0.007504

-0.294113
0.372480
0.718398







How can the PCA components be interpreted? The plot below shows the loadings of each PCA component for each input variable, the absolute values of which indicate the contribution of an input variable to the component value.

# Heatmap of the loadings
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
sns.heatmap(pca_loadings_df, cmap="YlGnBu", annot=True)
plt.title('PCA Loadings')
plt.show()









pca_bound = data_remaining.join(pd.DataFrame(pca_result, columns=['pca_component_1', 'pca_component_2', 'pca_component_3']))

We can also map the values of each component by precinct. PC1 appears to be correlated with areas in Northeast and South Philadelphia which are traditionally more Republican compared to the city average.

pca_bound.explore(column='pca_component_1', 
                   tiles="CartoDB positron", 
                   tooltip = ['precinct', 'turnout_change'], 
                   style_kwds = {'opacity' : 0})

Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook


PC2, as highlighted in the loadings plot, captures Latino-majority areas in North Philadelphia as well as University City, historically areas with low turnout.

pca_bound.explore(column='pca_component_2', 
                   tiles="CartoDB positron", 
                   tooltip = ['precinct', 'turnout_change'], 
                   style_kwds = {'opacity' : 0})

Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook


PC3 captures university areas most strongly.

pca_bound.explore(column='pca_component_3', 
                   tiles="CartoDB positron", 
                   tooltip = ['precinct', 'turnout_change'], 
                   style_kwds = {'opacity' : 0})

Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook


What is the relationship of the principal components with our turnout change measure? While the pattern is not perfectly clear, extremely low PC1 values are associated with decreased turnout, while extremely high PC2 and PC3 values are associated with increased turnout. Inspection of the extreme values show that these precincts are generally in University City, consistent with the patterns we saw in the previous section.

dropdown = alt.binding_select(
    options=['pca_component_1', 'pca_component_2', 'pca_component_3'],
    name='PCA component '
)

xcol_param = alt.param(
    value='pca_component_1',
    bind=dropdown
)

base = alt.Chart(pca_bound, title='Relationship between PCA components and turnout change').properties(
    width=400,
    height=400
).add_params(xcol_param)

interactive_scatter = base.mark_point(filled=True, size=15).encode(
    x=alt.X('x:Q', title=''),
    y=alt.Y('turnout_change:Q'),
    tooltip=['precinct']
).transform_calculate(
    x=f'datum[{xcol_param.name}]'
)

interactive_scatter

title: Descriptive analysis
text:
import pandas as pd
import geopandas as gpd
import numpy as np
import altair as alt
import re

title: Descriptive analysis
text:
Background
Philadelphia is divided into 1,703 electoral precincts, which are generally a few square blocks in size. From the Philadelphia City Commissioners website, I obtained precinct-level turnout and results from the 2024 and 2020 elections. From these data, I calculated the turnout rate as well as the Democratic share of the 2-party presidential vote, in both years. Demographic data at the census tract level was obtained from the American Community Survey (2023, 5-year), and joined to the precinct-level data based on the centroid of the precinct, calculated from shapefiles made available by the City of Philadelphia. (Because precinct boundaries do not nest with tract boundaries, the match is not exact, but generally tracts are significantly larger in size then precincts.)

# Read prepared data
input_data = gpd.read_file('data/prepared_data.geojson')

title: Descriptive analysis
text:
A first look
The interactive map below shows the turnout rate at each precinct in the 2024 election. Turnout varies grographically across the city, with precincts in Northwest Philadelphia and Northeast Philadelphia more likely to have higher turnout and precints in North and West Philadelphia more likely to have lower turnout.

# Plot map of turnout
input_data.explore(column='turnout_2024', 
                   tiles="CartoDB positron", 
                   tooltip = ['precinct', 'turnout_2024', 'turnout_2020', 'turnout_change'], 
                   style_kwds = {'opacity' : 0})

Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook


The histogram below shows the distibution of our measure of interest, turnout change. Far more precincts experienced declines in turnout than increases.

alt.Chart(input_data, title='Histogram of turnout change between 2020 and 2024').mark_bar().encode(
    alt.X("turnout_change", bin=True).title('Turnout change'),
    alt.Y('count()').title('Count of precincts')
)







This can also be seen in the map below, showing that turnout was depressed across much of the city compared to 2020, except for a few locations, especially around the universities in West and North Philadelphia.

# Plot map of turnout change
input_data.explore(column='turnout_change', 
                   tiles="CartoDB positron", 
                   cmap = 'PiYG', 
                   tooltip = ['precinct', 'turnout_change', 'turnout_2024', 'turnout_2020'], 
                   style_kwds = {'opacity' : 0})

Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook

title: Descriptive analysis
text:
A deeper look
We can examine more closely the other politico-demographic variables in our data. One possibility is that shifts in turnout are correlated with shifts in political leanings, given the overall Republican shift of the electorate in 2024 compared to 2020.
Below, an interactive scatterplot comparing turnout in 2024 vs 2020 is presented side-by-side with a histogram of turnout change by partisan shift.

# Create extra column for partisan changes between 2020 and 2024
input_data['party_shift_2024'] = np.where(input_data['pres_d_share_change'] > 0, 'Moved D', 'Moved R')


selector = alt.selection_point(fields=['party_shift_2024'])

color_scale = alt.Scale(domain=['Moved D', 'Moved R'],
                        range=['#475bf5', '#d13532'])

base = alt.Chart(input_data).properties(
    width=250,
    height=250
).add_params(selector)

points = base.mark_point(filled=True, size=200).encode(
    x=alt.X('turnout_2020:Q', scale=alt.Scale(domain=[0,1])),
    y=alt.Y('turnout_2024:Q', scale=alt.Scale(domain=[0,1])),
    color=alt.condition(selector,
                        'party_shift_2024:N',
                        alt.value('lightgray'),
                        scale=color_scale),
    tooltip=['precinct', 'turnout_change', 'pres_d_share_change']
)

hists = base.mark_bar(opacity=0.5, thickness=100).encode(
    x=alt.X('turnout_change',
            bin=alt.Bin(step=0.05), # step keeps bin size the same
            scale=alt.Scale(domain=[-0.3,0.3])
            ).title('Turnout change'),
    y=alt.Y('count()',
            stack=None,
            scale=alt.Scale(domain=[0,1200])
            ).title('Count of precincts'),
    color=alt.Color('party_shift_2024:N',
                    scale=color_scale)
).transform_filter(
    selector
)


points | hists







Looking at the histogram, it is clear that far more precincts experienced a shift toward the Republican candidate than toward the Democratic candidate, at least relative to the histocial majority-Democratic electorate in Philadelphia.
However, the shift in turnout does not seem to be substantially skewed by partisan shift, except for a few R-shifted precincts in the 27th and 24th wards (the points above the diagonal in the scatterplot), which are adjacent to Drexel and University of Pennsylvania.
The following interactive scatterplot allows you to choose between many explanatory variables on the x-axis. A clear relationship between these variables and turnout change is not readily descernible, except for the jump in turnout in the precincts with a high percentage of residents who are university students. This effect is also secondarily noticeable in other variables such as median income and rentership.

dropdown = alt.binding_select(
    options=['turnout_2020', 'pres_d_share_2024', 'pres_d_share_2020', 'pres_d_share_change', 
             'demographics_median_income', 'demographics_black_percentage', 'demographics_latino_percentage', 
             'demographics_renter_percentage', 'demographics_university_percentage'],
    name='X-axis column '
)

xcol_param = alt.param(
    value='turnout_2020',
    bind=dropdown
)

base = alt.Chart(input_data, title='Correlations between turnout change and selected variable').properties(
    width=400,
    height=400
).add_params(xcol_param)

interactive_scatter = base.mark_point(filled=True, size=15).encode(
    x=alt.X('x:Q', title=''),
    y=alt.Y('turnout_change:Q'),
    tooltip=['precinct', 'turnout_change', 'x:Q']
).transform_calculate(
    x=f'datum[{xcol_param.name}]'
)

interactive_scatter







In sum, there is a clear effect of increased turnout in student-deavy precincts, very likely driven by the pandemic-specific effects in 2020, when many university students were not in residence at school.

title: Introduction
text:
Introduction
In the 2024 presidential election, Philadelphia was expected to be a crucial battleground for votes in Pennsylvania, and thus potentially to be pivotal for the outcome of the race as a whole. However, the number of votes cast in Philadelphia declined from the last presidential election in 2020, from 749,317 in the earlier year to 727,595. The turnout rate, which is the ratio of votes cast to registered voters, was also lower in 2024 (65.10%) compared to 2020 (66.35%).
What explains the lower turnout? In this analysis, we look at how several different electoral and demographic factors may have influenced turnout changes between 2024 and 2020.

title: Introduction
text:
Introduction
In the 2024 presidential election, Philadelphia was expected to be a crucial battleground for votes in Pennsylvania, and thus potentially to be pivotal for the outcome of the race as a whole. However, the number of votes cast in Philadelphia declined from the last presidential election in 2020, from 749,317 in the earlier year to 727,595. The turnout rate, which is the ratio of votes cast to registered voters, was also lower in 2024 (65.10%) compared to 2020 (66.35%).
What explains the lower turnout? In this analysis, we look at how several different electoral and demographic factors may have influenced turnout changes between 2024 and 2020.
